Liquidity floats all, but manage risks in crowded spaces

Our aggregate measure of investor positioning in Asia now sits around the \(85\mathrm{th}\) %ile (having gone as high as \(97^{\mathrm{th}}\) %ile in July - Figure 1). While this would normally be considered a significant headwind, the global policy easing and China liquidity surge currently underway is providing a strong counter force. In this context, we believe the equity bull market will remain intact and any correction/ consolidation will present a buying opportunity. However, it is important to manage risks where positioning is particularly crowded. Looking across LO, HF and Quant investors, we note the highest crowding in Taiwan Tech/Semis and Indo Financials, followed by China Growth stocks (semis, consumer and biotech). Alongside this, ongoing support from monetary policy should eventually warrant a widening of the leadership and outperformance of Cyclicals. We are upgrading the Materials sector to Ow in the AxJ region following our recent allocation changes in India (see report). Within the AxJ region, our pecking order is Korea > India > China > Taiwan > ASEAN. Our key OwS are: China Tech, Internet, Healthcare, Materials, select Financial/Industrials; India Financials, Consumer ex Auto, Materials, Real Estate, Hospitals, select power/defense; Korea Financials, Tech, Holdco; TSMC in Taiwan; and ASEAN Financials, Real Estate, Utilities, Healthcare, IT.

- Crowded market segments in Asia: For LO investors, their key OwS are in China Internet, China Consumer, Taiwan Tech, Korea Tech, India Banks and Indo Banks (Figure 8). Among single stocks, relative to benchmark weight, most crowded positions are in BCA, TME, Netease, Hana, Kia, Mediatek and Delta. For HFs, net positioning is currently most elevated in Cap Goods, Tech (Hardware and Semis) and Financial Services (Figure 11). For AI and Semis overall, JPM Prime book data show record high net positioning in both Mag 7 stocks and in US Semiconductors sector (Figure 12-13). From a factor lens, Growth is starting to look crowded in China after the recent strong performance (Figure 16). Crowding in Momentum in Korea is starting to unwind, but still elevated. Quality/Growth looks extremely crowded in Taiwan. Across all of North Asia, Defensives and Value look extremely uncrowded. No factor looks particularly crowded or uncrowded in India.

- Positioning themes by market: (1) China: The recent surge in onshore liquidity may be temporary, but, longer-term, apart from national team purchases and household re-allocation from cash/MMF into equities, there are also sticky institutional flows from private pensions, new insurance premiums, and regulators' mandates on 10% annual increase in mutual funds' equity holdings. (2) Taiwan: With EM/Asia investors starting to hit mandate constraints on TSMC again, we note that global funds, global TMT funds, hedge funds and sovereign investors are likely all unconstrained in terms of room to buy. For the largest of these cohorts, global funds have so far only neutralized previous UWs in the stock. (3) Korea: While retail investors are yet to meaningfully re-allocate towards local equities, the decline in their

Taking into account NXT flows, which now make up a third of Korea's trading volumes, retail participation remains in the \(60 - 65\%\) range. (4) India: We recently introduced comprehensive positioning tracking across different investor types at the stock level in India (see report). The dominant position of DIIs continues to strengthen – most recently bolstered by growth in Alternative Investment Funds (AIFs). (5) ASEAN: Local fund support is also emerging in ASEAN – with Malaysia and Singapore leading the charge, while Thailand and Vietnam have seen more retail buying.

- Market-sector positioning trends of LO investors: Over 2Q 25, investor positioning increased in China cyclicals, India Financials, Telco, Discretionary and Internet, and Taiwan non-Tech. On the other hand, investors reduced allocations in Taiwan Tech and Financials, China consumer, Korea Internet and exporters, and India IT (Figure 32-33).- At a single stock level, Figures 41-43 show key single-stock overweights, underweights and off-benchmark holdings for the 150 largest EM and AxJ mutual funds. The top 10 stocks with increased investor allocations were: HDFC, Tencent, Baba, Netease, Delta, CATL, MMYT, Bharti, M&M, SK Square. Top top 10 stocks with reduced investor allocations were TSMC (mandate constraints), JD, Doosan Enerbility, Meituan, VIPS, Naver, Infosys, Hyundai motor, CMB, Hon Hai. Among the largest stocks in the index, we show the most and least well-held stocks by LO investors in Figure 7.

In our previous positioning update in May, we flagged that positioning was no longer light (a bi- directional risk), but that MXASJ still had room (and positive catalysts) to take it higher towards our bull case target (825). We have now slightly breached this level. And while our aggregate positioning metric has moved up to the \(85\mathrm{th}\%\) (having gone as high as \(97^{\mathrm{th}}\%\) ) and would normally be considered a significant headwind, the global policy easing and China liquidity surge currently underway is providing a strong counter force. In this context, it is useful to focus on where, in particular, positioning is most crowded. Overall, looking across LO, HF and Quant investors, we note crowding in Taiwan Tech/Semis and Indo Financials, followed by China Growth stocks (semis, consumer and biotech).

LO investors: EM/Asia investors biggest OW positions relative to benchmark weights are in Indo Financials, Korea Autos and China Consumer. On the other hand, investors are quite UW (relative to benchmark weight) in China Tech, Taiwan Financials, Malaysia and India Staples. We note, in conjunction, that the pace of overall foreign flows is presently most elevated in Indonesia and most depressed in India. Among single stocks, relative to benchmark weight, most crowded positions are in BCA, TME, Netease, Hana, Kia, Mediatek and Delta.

HF investors: Based on data in the JPM Prime book data from the JPM Positioning Intelligence team, we note that net positioning is currently most elevated in Cap Goods, Tech (Hardware and Semis) and Financial Services. Financial services and Biotech have seen the largest increases in positioning in 3Q so far. On the other hand, Insurance positioning remains deeply negative, followed by Property, Energy, Transportation and Healthcare equipment. As for AI and Semis overall, the team also highlights record high net positioning in both Mag 7 stocks and in the US Semiconductors sector.

Quant/Systematic: Momentum- driven investors have likely increased positions in China onshore most recently, while cutting Korea exposures. From a factor lens, Growth is starting to look crowded in China after the recent strong performance. Crowding in Momentum in Korea is starting to unwind, but still elevated. Quality/ Growth looks extremely crowded in Taiwan. Across all of North Asia, Defensives and Value look extremely uncrowded. No factor looks particularly crowded or uncrowded in India.

Through 1Q 2025, light positioning had been a tailwind, allowing markets to weather risk events. This went to an extreme in early April, as our aggregate measure of investor positioning in Asia (measuring across LO, HF, Deriv, retail, FX investors) fell to its lowest level since our tracking started in 2019. Since April 7 (when we called for market upside given extreme tariff pessimism and low positioning), markets have staged a remarkable rally - now up \(>30\%\) . In our previous positioning update in May, we flagged that positioning was no longer light (a bi- directional risk), but that MXASJ still had room (and positive catalysts) to take it higher towards our bull case target (825). We have now slightly breached this level and our aggregate positioning metric briefly moved above the \(90^{\text{th}}\) percentile, but the global easing liquidity is providing a strong counter force.

Apart from the beta exposure discussed above, we look at investors' exposure by key theme/sector within the region. For this granular assessment, we aggregate the holdings data of \(150+\) largest EM and Asia ex Japan funds and isolate allocations strictly among EM Asia equities (i.e., excluding allocations to other regions or to cash) at a single- stock level. Investors' key OWs are in China Internet, China Consumer, Taiwan Tech, Korea Tech, India Banks and Indo Banks. Key UWs are in Taiwan Financials, China Financials and Tech, Malaysia, India Commodities and Consumer, and Korea Industrials.

Alpha generation from this allocation has been mixed in recent months. While Korea and Taiwan Tech have helped performance, China Internet performance has lagged, and the best- performing sector (Korea Industrials) is a space where investors are broadly UW.
Figure 31: EM/Asia long-only funds' allocations vs performance (YTD) by market-sector
Source: Bloomberg Finance L.P., J.P. Morgan Equity Macro Research.

In terms of investors' allocation changes in 2Q 2025, we note increases in China cyclicals, India Financials, Telco, Discretionary and Internet, and Taiwan non-Tech. On the other hand, investors reduced allocations in Taiwan Tech and Financials, China consumer, Korea Internet and exporters, and India IT.
The top 15 stocks with increased investor allocations were: HDFC, Tencent, Baba, Netease, Delta, CATL, MMYT, Bharti, M&M, SK Square, Indigo, CR Land. ASPEED, TME, and China Pacific Insurance.

Top top 15 stocks with reduced investor allocations were TSMC (mandate constraints), JD, Doosan Enertility, Meituan, VIPS, Naver, Infosys, Hyundai Motor, CMB, Hon Hai, BRI, Trip.com, Samsung Life, Kakao and Axis Bank.

At a single-stock level, the figures below show the largest single-stock overweights, underweights and off-benchmark holdings for the 150 largest EM and AxJ mutual funds. On average, the top OW stocks have outperformed the top UW stocks by 2.7% YTD. We note that outperforming underweight stocks – Doosan Enerbility, Hon Hai, Quanta – are most likely to have further flow tailwinds from here.

Among the larger stocks, the most widely held are Bharti and KMB in India, Delta and Mediatek in Taiwan, Netease and Ping An in China, KB in Korea and BCA in Indo. The least widely held stocks are BAF, L&T and Huvr in India, Xiaomi, CCB, JD, Baidu and AgBank in China, Quanta, CTBC and Fubon in Taiwan, and Hyundai Motor and NAVER in Korea.

Southbound has become the top source of inflows for Hong Kong listed China equities during the current rally

Southbound turnover has risen to \(28\%\) of Hong Kong's total market turnover, up from \(18\%\) in 2024 and \(15\%\) in 2023. By industry group, Bank led significantly in terms of 1- year inflow at RMB215bn, followed by Discretionary Retail (RMB208bn), and Non- Bank Financials (RMB120bn). This implies that mainland investors are increasingly drawn to high- yielding stocks in Hong Kong, due to the low- yield environment in the mainland and regulatory support for long- term asset allocation (e.g., raising equity allocation \(1\%\) for insurers).

For SB holdings by sector, Energy led at \(28\%\) , followed by Health Care (25%) and Information Technology (20%), while Consumer Staples and Real Estate lagged the most. By YTD SB holding change, Healthcare saw the largest increase of \(6\%\) , due to the improving growth outlook for Biotech on out- licensing deals, followed by Energy and Materials, likely driven by the rising expectations of the anti- involution policy that bolsters the pricing and profitability outlook.

From Sept- 24 to Jun- 25, the national and quasi- national team bought Rmb2trn of A- shares, while mutual funds saw c.- Rmb0.2trn net redemption. However, from Sept- 24 through 21 Aug, the margin balance rose by Rmb0.8trn. TINA has been a driving factor for the institutional asset allocation shift from bonds to equities. JPM estimates additional institutional inflows of Rmb1.65trn to equities per year till 2027. Since July, retail- driven margin balance and new mutual fund issuance have risen, despite weakening macro data. Investors we spoke to expect an upside bias before China's Victory Day Parade (Sep- 3) and a potential Fed rate cut (Sep 18) to help cushion the interim downside (see Assessing the current liquidity charged rally, Aug 25 2025 ).

One of the key assertions for our bullish thesis on Korea is for local retail investors to (over time) redirect more of their capital towards the local equity market. While this has yet to happen in a material way, looking at the most common measure of retail net buying of Korean equities (based on KRX data) is also somewhat misleading. This is because the launch of the Nextrade (NXT) trading venue in Korea in March has had a substantial impact on market structure. The new trading venue has a pre- market session and an after- market session. Particularly the pre- market is proving popular with retail investors to express a view on US/overnight news. As a result, NXT now captures over \(30\%\) of total Korea turnover and over \(40\%\) of retail turnover. JPM's Market Structure team notes that this is substantially larger than any alternative trading venue globally. We note that: (1) Adjusting for NXT trading, overall trading volumes in Korea have not really declined, and are presently up \(70\%\) YTD. (2) Retail participation in the market has not declined (to \(50\%\) in KRX data) and is holding steady in the \(60 - 65\%\) range. (3) Retail net selling is a lot less severe than implied by KRX data only.
Additionally, we note three channels of potentially improving supply- demand in the equity market ahead:

(1) Money market funds in Korea have grown to over \(160bn. With declining money market rates (and the BOK expected to cut rates further), some of this liquidity is inevitably going to find its way to the equity market - somewhat similar (if at a smaller scale) to what is happening in China (discussed above).

(2) Corporate buybacks have picked up in Korea substantially this year (to \(\sim 1\%\) of market cap run rate). This has led to a moderation in the net issuance/dilution trend (which is common in emerging markets) such that net dilution (issuance net of buybacks) is now actually negative since mid-2024.

(3) We have discussed previously the notable lack of home bias among Korean retail investors (with almost half as much in US equity holdings as in direct domestic equity and funds holdings). While Korean buying of US equities hit record highs in April-June, some repatriation ahead is not unreasonable given the extent to which US equities (and even crypto assets) have underperformed local equities in local currency terms YTD.

EM/Asia investors are again facing mandate constraints on holding TSMC. TSMC is not only \(55\%\) of MSCI Taiwan, it is also \(11.7\%\) of MSCI Asia ex- Japan and \(10.4\%\) of MSCI EM. This makes it hard for many EM and Asia funds to hold even equal weight positions in the stock. On the one hand, this is a challenge for such funds because there continues to be a big divergence between the strong performance of TSMC vs the underperformance of the market outside of TSMC (driven by a difference in earnings cyclicality, margin moat, investor ownership and participation, etc.).

On the other hand, we estimate that over \(50\%\) of TSMC's shareholders are unable to meaningfully add to their positions from here: being either local (and unlikely to raise allocation), passive benchmarked (ETF or otherwise) or mandate constrained (EM/Asia investors).

For the market, thus, it becomes relevant to think where incremental buyers of the stock will come from. Global funds (including global, international and global growth), global TMT funds (on aggregate likely over 5x smaller than the broader global funds in their TSMC holdings), hedge funds and sovereign investors are likely all unconstrained in terms of their ability to buy. For the largest of these cohorts, our sample set of global funds covering \(\) 3\mathrm{tn}\$ in AUM suggests that these global investors have so far only neutralized previous UWs in the stock. Global investors' interest in TSMC can be easiest seen in the premium of the ADR to the local line.

FIIs turned buyers in the Jun'25 quarter after tariff delays, buying \(5.4bn vs selling\) 13.5bn in the Mar'25 quarter, driven by the 90- day tariff pause and hopes of a growth recovery on the back of monetary policy easing. On the domestic side, DII flows remained robust with buying of \(19.7bn in the quarter vs\) 21.8bn in the Mar quarter. Retail investors sold \(1.5bn of equities during the same period (vs\) 0.8bn of buying). July and Aug so far have witnessed FII outflow of \(4.7bn, with DIIs offsetting it with a strong\) 14.6bn inflow, smartly supported by Retail inflow of \(0.8bn (Figure 78). This has pushed the DII/FII ownership ratio to its historical peak of slightly more than1.0 for the BSE 500 universe (from an all- time low of 0.4 in Mar- 15, almost over a decade back) (Figure 79).

Domestic mutual funds (DMFs) have emerged as a key support for the equity market as investors have been pouring in higher sums through Systematic Investment Plans (SIPs). Total amount collected through SIP during July 2025 was INR 28,464 cr (US\$3.25bn). SIP stoppage ratio has subsided in the June quarter and July, post the spike in the Mar'25 quarter. July 2025 saw a record all- time high monthly inflow into equities at 42,702cr (\$4.9bn), signalling renewed investor appetite after a relatively moderate June Q (Figure 81). While inflows increased across the schemes, sectoral and thematic funds registered the largest gain, pulling in INR 9,426cr (\~\$1.1bn).

Driven by increasing interest from UHNs and family offices, total commitments to Alternative Investment Funds (AIFs) soared past INR 14tn (\~\$163bn) as of June 2025 (Figure 84), marking 20% YoY growth. Of the investments made, Real estate constitutes \(\sim 12.5\%\) of the total investments, making it the largest sector, followed by financial services, IT, NBFCs, and Banks. Last month, the RBI announced relaxed regulations on investments by its regulated entities, including banks and NBFCs, in AIFs, setting a limit of 20% for cumulative exposure to schemes and 10% for a single entity's exposure to the scheme's corpus.

FIIs preferred to increase their ownership in Mid caps. Sectorally, FIIs sold IT while there was more buying into Financials and Comm. Services. On the other hand, DMFs mildly cut their underweight in Staples, Industrials and Materials. As of Jun'25, FIIs remain significantly overweight in Financials and Comm. Services, while maintaining substantial underweights in Staples, Materials, and Industrials. Similarly, DMFs are heavily underweight in Materials, Industrials, and Staples, and are overweight in Financials, Discretionary, and Health Care (see our latest positioning note here for more).

FIIs have offloaded approximately \(\sim\) \$13.1bn over the last two years, despite significant increases in weights in benchmark regional equity indices of India equities, leading to a more pronounced net under- positioning. Among different LO investor groups, we see Global, Global- ex- US, Asia- ex- Japan and Emerging Markets funds most underweight India. However, Asia- ex- Japan funds have reduced their average underweight by 245bps over the last 6 months to 4.2% in June 2025 (Figure 83).

Top large-cap names bought by FIIs for the Jun'25 quarter were Bharti Airtel, ICICI Bank, HDFC Bank, Indigo and ITC while top sells were TCS, Infosys, NTPC, Eternal and SBI. Over 2Q, EM/Asia LO investors' top bought positions in India were HDFC, Bharti, MMYT, Mahindra and Indigo. On the other hand, funds were sellers of Infosys, Axis Bank, Sun Pharma, GAIL and Embassy REIT.

The announcement of trade deals and new tariff rates (19- 20% reciprocal tariffs in general, except 10% for Singapore) - has cleared uncertainties and improved investor sentiment in the region. That said, foreign flows remain lackluster, with inflows being strongest in Indonesia (+US\$334mn), followed by the Philippines (+US\$30mn), whilst the rest of ASEAN still witnessed foreigners withdrawing.

A weaker dollar and lower oil prices should enable ASEAN central banks to accelerate monetary easing. This, combined with fiscal support turning positive, could mark an inflection in earnings expectations for the region and attract flows (see our note). Singapore and Vietnam have been leading regional markets in terms of fiscal support so far this year, which has strong implications for earnings trends and stock market performance. We believe other ASEAN countries will join the bandwagon. Indonesia has pledged to ramp up stimulus on top of the \(\) 1.5bn\(package rolled out in June, and while tax revenue remains a risk, lower interest rates could give the government. optionality to provide more fiscal support. Malaysia has recently unveiled cash handouts and fuel price support. The Philippines has pushed back its fiscal consolidation plan and maintained the deficit at a high level. Thailand is drafting its 2026 budget with an expansionary stance (JPMec deficit/GDP at 4.5% in 2026 vs. 4.0% in 2025). Excess liquidity in the Thai banking system would support government finances in, our view.

Cash deployment started with Malaysian domestic institutions. Local fund managers in Malaysia raised deployed 1.3pt cash in June, bringing cash allocation down to \(\sim 10.3\%\) . Sector allocation has turned to favor cyclicals, including Tech, Industrials, and Utilities whilst Banks, Healthcare, and Consumer were trimmed.

Thailand saw \~US\(500mn of flows reversal in July, driving the market up by more 14%, the strongest in EM/Asia. Inflows were strongest in Transportation (AOT), Banking (KBANK, BBL), Commerce (CPALL), Utilities (GULF), and Property (CPN). However, the cumulative amount of net-selling by foreign investors remains large (US\)1.8bn YTD). Local institutions also increased their exposure by adding \~US\)150mn in July. Local retail investors turned to net selling (US\)615mn) after a long period of net buying.
